sned J-fornine q body Of able bodied mel of n,
enteen in number. There never wasa happier MN
than Cook was the day that We arrived; he n,std
our presence and cooperstion. The fraternity in md
about l.. wi:ton were in q terrible stew al our sn,,
and threatened wonderfully. We paid no a,tsnlionn

at public house, and Cook informed DR. .....

gan's request for bible was Not granted, tWh

Batnria Jan 2sth 1927.


Dear Sir--Your iavor o! the 22d received last
evening, aher | returned from Lewiston, where

oihy FiUh Aite; absence uf four days in pur

and respt ptctsble representation from Ontario sn6

We succeeded II aserrtenlng beyond doubt, and
is su ceptibe OF proof, that -, and -, and 9th
ers, took Morgan 10 fort Niagara, the night oil
the 3th September, before the installation Of The
chapter at Lewiston. We ascettsined beyond rea-
sonable doubt Il ON respectable mastn oil hieh de-
gree, in Newark, U. &. that Morgan wa, confined
in The magazine at Fort Niagara; that on the night
OF the l4th he was tried, condemned, and executed,
by having his throat cut from ear to carr his tongue
taken out and buried in he sand and his body sunk
in the lake or river. Our informant said, iha, on,
masons expected that Morgan would have been re-
ceived BY their masons, and hBnded over 10 Brapt.
or sent on board a British man OF war. Their lodpe
met and Brnnt was sent for and the resuIs was, that
their ledge would not receive him consequently,
he was despatched oil this side withou, aowpc him
to have bible and ligh, hall an hour, which he
earnestly requested lie also stated tha, Miller was
expected with Morgan; that it was done at the ,x-
pensc and by the direction OF the grand chapter OF
the state OF New York. This mans statement was
corroboraed by many strong circumstances and
statements Of nasons on this side.


Cldngs, who has been sergeant in our service
and is mason. and keeps the ferry and public house
at the fort, stated, that on the night of the 4h there

whom took supper, about / o'clock Among
those who took supper, he knew five or six,
-, --, --, the other names | have
forgotten, On the morning Of the 18Th, about fou,
O'Clock, --, and others, were seen on foo
near Lewiston. During the 18th an express arrived

horse, and hitch It beside the under the shed
that man would come end lake i, that there was
noise at the Tort that the horse might no, 1e,urt
until in the night; when il did he mus, take care
II. These were --'s directions The hors,
did not return until after he went to bed which va
O'Clock that---t told him the next morn
E ing, that II was still enough at the fort then!

Dear Sir-t wrote you las, evening, and hope

From the Albany Observer.
q MURDER WILL OUT J"
full articles.article:
phenomenon, Of which there is no precedent in the
history of the human mind had they been satisfied,
after knowing that he was violently and illegally
carried off without likewise knowing what had oeen
done with him. His kidnappers confessed their
guilt Immediately on this confession, and conse'
ouent conviction, these simple but deeply important
que stions present themselves 10 the minds OF the
peope, and with such force that they cannot rest
quietly under them, viz: Since the guilty confess
lhst they carried him away, what did they 90 with
him? How did they dispose OF him DID ihey
leave him dead or alive II dead, how came ne oy
his death? IL alive, where is he These questions,
We repeat il, are simple. but they come in voice
OF thunder 10 every honest heart they quicken Inc
moral sense Of every friend to liberty and humanl-
ty; they in,gorate curiosity 10 discover the dark
tracks Of the murderer; and they appeal, with re-
siscss foIce, to the spirit OF justice lhat Loo mas
planted in The human breast.


Under this excitement, this heaven.born spirit oil
eternal justice. numerous meetings havs been held
lin Genesee, Monroe, Ontario, SC. since the trial
At Canandsigua; ana among other saluiary and pru-
Dental measures, board Of delegates were chosen,
eighteen in number, one OF whcm, however, shruDk
from hi, duty, being threatened )-.hese delegates,
composed OF the mort respectable men IN society,
proceeded in body to the British side OF The Mag
ara and after Iaborious, il not thorough inses-
tie alton, they have returned, having, to their per-





awful and tremendous facts


| Firstly hat the unhappy Morgan was taken TO
Newark. Y. c gagged, bound and blind folded
Secondly he was there offered TO the Bill
tish Mssons Of that place. with request that they
should get him on board Of British man Of arar.
or turn him orer TO Drant, the Indian chief and a
mason, to BE- executed uith sardge cruelty


Thirdly--That the Newark ndge assembled, on
this ptoposilion and sent for Bran, who came aeeor
dinghy.


Four,hly- Bran. proved himself too much no
bic Of nature, 10 have any thing TO do with SO COW
ardy, iuhumsn, and wicked transaction. The
savage hero disdaned to do that, which cowardly
white monsters urged him to do


| Ffthy-the Newark masons, thus rcbuked by
savage Justice and msgnanimi,y, likewise finally
declined TO lake charge OF the miserable victim.
| Sxhy--The diabolie al wretcbes who had him in
custody, brought him back as lar as Fort Niagara
and there murdered him in cold blood cutting his
throat from TO car cutting out his tongue, and
burying i, in the sand and concluding the hesh
rites BY sinking his body deep in The lake
But the mutitudnous waves OF that lake shall
never wash from the souls OF those ure,ches, the
bloody stains Of tina, night of horror and Of crime
We now come TO the proofs and they are as
strong, as can be expected, in case involved in
such darkness and mystery, in which so many have
taken part, and are SO deeply interested in con.
